# Á•ûÁªèÁΩëÁªúÂü∫Á°Ä

## 1.Binary Classification

- In a binary classification problem, the result is a discrete value output

- ExampleÔºöCat vs Non-Cat

  ![](D:\ImportantFiles\ÁßëÁõÆ\Â§ß‰∏â‰∏ã\Ê∑±Â∫¶Â≠¶‰π†\Á•ûÁªèÁΩëÁªúÂü∫Á°Ä\catvsnoncat.PNG)

  To create a feature vector, ùë•, the pixel intensity values will be ‚Äúunroll‚Äù or ‚Äúreshape‚Äù for each color. The
  dimension of the input feature vector ùë• is ùëõùë• = 64 ùë• 64 ùë• 3 = 12 288.

  ![](D:\ImportantFiles\ÁßëÁõÆ\Â§ß‰∏â‰∏ã\Ê∑±Â∫¶Â≠¶‰π†\Á•ûÁªèÁΩëÁªúÂü∫Á°Ä\vector.PNG)

- some notations:

  ![](D:\ImportantFiles\ÁßëÁõÆ\Â§ß‰∏â‰∏ã\Ê∑±Â∫¶Â≠¶‰π†\Á•ûÁªèÁΩëÁªúÂü∫Á°Ä\notation.PNG)

## 2.Logistics Regression

Logistic regression is a learning algorithm used in a supervised learning problem when the output ùë¶ are
all either 0 or 1. The goal of logistic regression is to minimize the error between its predictions and training data

- ExampleÔºöCat vs Non-Cat

  ‚Äã                                        ùê∫ùëñùë£ùëíùëõ ùë• , ùë¶ÃÇ = ùëÉ(ùë¶ = 1|ùë•), where 0 ‚â§ ùë¶ÃÇ ‚â§ 1

  The parameters used in Logistic regression are:
  ‚Ä¢ The input features vector: $x\in R^{n_x}$, where $n_x$ is the number of features
  ‚Ä¢ The training label:$y\in {0,1}$
  ‚Ä¢ The weights: $w\in R^{n_x}$, where  $n_x$ is the number of features
  ‚Ä¢ The threshold: $b\in R$
  ‚Ä¢ The output: $\hat{y}=\sigma(w^Tx+b)$
  ‚Ä¢ Sigmoid function:  $s=\sigma(w^Tx+b)=\sigma(z)=\frac{1}{1+e^{-z}}$

  ![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

## 3.logisticÂõûÂΩíÊçüÂ§±ÂáΩÊï∞

yÁöÑÈ¢ÑÊµãÂÄºÔºö$\hat{y}=\sigma(w^Tx+b)$

sigmoidÂáΩÊï∞Ôºö$\sigma(z)=\frac{1}{1+e^{-z}}$
Loss function(ÊçüÂ§±ÂáΩÊï∞)Ôºö$L( \hat{y}, y)=-(ylog\hat{y} + (1-y)log(1-\hat{y}) )$

Cost function(ÊàêÊú¨ÂáΩÊï∞)Ôºö$J(w,b)=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}L(\hat{y}^{(i)},y^{(i)})=-\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}[(\hat{y}^{(i)}log(\hat{y}^{(i)})+(1-y^{(i)})log(1-\hat{y})^{(i)})]$



## 4.computation graphÔºàËÆ°ÁÆóÂõæÔºâ

![img](https://ss1.bdstatic.com/70cFuXSh_Q1YnxGkpoWK1HF6hhy/it/u=3157507271,2235260224&fm=15&gp=0.jpg)

- chain ruleÔºö$\frac{dJ}{dc}=\frac{dJ}{dv}\frac{dv}{du}\frac{du}{dc}$ 

## 5.Ê¢ØÂ∫¶‰∏ãÈôç

### ÂéüÁêÜ

1. ÂçïÊ†∑Êú¨Ê¢ØÂ∫¶‰∏ãÈôç

$$
z=w^Tx+b\\
\hat{y}=a=\sigma(z)\\
L(a,y)=-(ylog(a)+(1-y)log(1-a))
$$

$da=\frac{dL(a,y)}{da}\to dz=\frac{dL}{dz}=\frac{dL}{da}\frac{da}{dz}\to dw\&db$

2. m‰∏™Ê†∑Êú¨Ê¢ØÂ∫¶‰∏ãÈôç
   $$
   J(w,b)=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}L(a^{(i)},y^{(i)})\\
   a^{(i)}=\hat{y}^{(i)}=\sigma(z^{(i)})=\sigma(w^Tx+b)
   $$
   

### ÂÆûÁé∞

- forÂæ™ÁéØÂÆûÁé∞

  1. $for\ i=1 \to m:\\$
     $$
     \ \ z^{(i)}=w^Tx+b\\
     \ \ a^{(i)}=\sigma(z^{(i)})\\
     \ \ J+=-[y^{(i)}loga^{(i)}+(1-y^{(i)})log(1-a^{(i)})]\\
     dz^{(i)}=a^{(i)}-y^{(i)}\\
     $$
     ‚Äã        $for\ j=1\to n:$
     $$
     dw_1+=x_1^{(i)}dz^{(i)}\\
     dw_2+=x_2^{(i)}dz^{(i)}\\
     ...\\
     dw_n+=x_n^{(i)}dz^{(i)}\\
     db+=dz^{(i)}\\
     $$
     
  2. $J/=m;dw_1/=m;dw_2/=m;...;dw_n/=m;\\db/=m$
  
  3. $w_1=w_1-\alpha dw_1;w_2=w_2-\alpha dw_2;...;w_n=w_n-\alpha dw_n;\\b=b-\alpha db$
  
- ÂêëÈáèÂåñÂÆûÁé∞
  $$
  Z=[z^{(1)},z^{(2)},...,z{(m)}]\\
  X=\begin{bmatrix}
  x_1^{(1)}&x_1^{(2)}&...&x_1^{(m)}\\
  x_2^{(1)}&x_2^{(2)}&...&x_2^{(m)}\\
  \vdots&\vdots&\ &\vdots \\
  x_n^{(1)}&x_n^{(2)}&...&x_n^{(m)}\\
  \end{bmatrix}\\
  w^T=\begin{bmatrix}
  
  \end{bmatrix}\\
  b=\begin{matrix}
  \underbrace{[b\ b\ \cdots b]}\\m
  \end{matrix}\\
  \implies Z=w^TX+b=np.dot(w.T,X)+b\\A=\sigma(Z)\\
  dZ=A-Y\\dw=\frac{1}{m}XdZ^T,\\db=\frac{1}{m}np.sum(dZ)
  $$
